question: How does increasing the extinction depth affect the ET–head relationship? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Yes. Larger EXDP means a wider range of elevations over which partial ET occurs but does not affect the maximum rate.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. EXDP changes the shape and range of the Q-h curve, but not the maximum ET rate.

question: What happens to the ET rate if the groundwater head is below the extinction depth? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. Below extinction depth, actual ET is zero by definition and thus MODFLOW is assuming it is negligible.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. ET is only nonzero above the  extinction depth.

question: Which parameter directly controls the **maximum rate** of groundwater evapotranspiration in MODFLOW? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. EVTR defines the evapotranspiration rate. SURF and EXDP shape the relationship between elevation and rate. Cell area converts the low rate to the volumetric discharge from a model cell.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. EVTR area defines the maximum evapotranspiration rate. SURF and EXDP shape the relationship between elevation and rate. Cell area converts the low rate to the volumetric discharge from a model cell.

question: What is the **role of SURF** (ET surface) in the MODFLOW EVT package? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Good! SURF sets the upper elevation bound for evapotranspiration rate less than the maximum rate, but not the rate itself.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. SURF doesn’t define the evapotranspiration rate — it defines the upper elevation bound for evapotranspiration rate less than the maximum rate, but not the rate itself.

question: Which scenarios would justify a large extinction depth in an ET boundary? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Yes. A large EXDP reflects deep root systems or long capillary connections.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. Only the presence of vegetation with access to deep groundwater justifies large EXDP.
